fields.headline: Tsunami news in brief
fields.bodyText: · Barry Lloyd-Jones, 68, a journalist from Warwickshire, is among those still missing from Koh Lak, Thailand. His wife Kath, 56, was found alive 100 miles further south four days after the disaster. · An Australian hailed as a hero for reportedly rescuing more than a dozen tsunami victims was arrested on assault and burglary charges as he arrived at Brisbane airport. Police said they recognised Thomas Connell, 32, after he gave a TV interview in Thailand. · Police have arrested 30 looters in southern Thailand who stole electrical goods from hotels and businesses. · A 23-year-old Indonesian man swept out to sea by the tsunami was found floating on tree branches and debris, the second person to be found alive at sea by Malaysian ships days after the disaster, officials said. · The head of Thailand's met office was transferred from his job yesterday for failing to issue a warning of the approaching tsunami, the prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, said. · The EU is considering creating a 5,000-strong "crisis management corps" to deal with disasters such as the tsunamis, the EU's external relations commissioner, Benita Ferrero-Waldner, told the Financial Times. · European tour operators plan to restart offering holidays in stricken countries. Frances Tuke, an Abta spokeswoman, said: "By staying away we just increase the impact [of the tsunami] for these people."
